analysis.title: This Wedding Is Fucked
analysis.author: Erica Bardin & Susan Graham
analysis.logline: When ex-couple Melissa and Jonathan find themselves as maid of honor and best man at her sister's destination wedding, their escalating revenge pranks spiral out of control, threatening both the ceremony and their own unresolved feelings.
analysis.tone: Raunchy, farcical comedy with moments of genuine emotional resonance

concept.justification: The premise of warring exes sabotaging a destination wedding is immediately clear, commercially appealing, and offers rich comedic potential. The concept requires minimal explanation and provides a perfect sandbox for escalating comedy.

structure.justification: The screenplay has a clear structure with strong time markers (countdown to wedding), effective act breaks, and escalating complications. The pacing occasionally slackens in the second act with repetitive prank sequences, but maintains momentum toward the climactic hotel fire.

protagonist.justification: Melissa and Jonathan function as dual protagonists with clear, opposing goals that evolve naturally. Both have agency, drive the plot forward, and experience meaningful character arcs as they realize their pettiness has damaged others. Their transformation feels earned through catastrophe.

supporting_cast.justification: The ensemble is colorful and distinct, particularly Nicole (high-strung bride), Bradford (Melissa's fake gay boyfriend), and Jasper (Jonathan's crass friend). Minor characters like Vlad and Gabi have memorable personalities. Some secondary characters (Leah, Bette, Edward) remain somewhat underdeveloped.

dialogue.justification: The dialogue is sharp, contemporary, and character-specific. Nicole's control-freak dialogue contrasts with Bradford's theatrical speech patterns. The script includes numerous quotable lines ("Don't tase me bro"), effective running gags, and strong comedic rhythm.

genre_execution.justification: The screenplay delivers the expected comedy set pieces of wedding films (rehearsal dinners, toasts gone wrong) with fresh, outrageous twists. It balances raunchy humor with emotional stakes effectively, and the escalation of pranks pays off in satisfying ways.

originality.justification: While working within familiar wedding comedy and ex-lovers territory, the script finds fresh angles through its dual-protagonist perspective, audacious pranks (taser card game, kidnapping), and willingness to go big (literally burning down the wedding venue).

major_weaknesses: Some supporting characters remain underdeveloped despite screen time

target_audience.note: Clear appeal to 18-35 demographic who attend R-rated comedies

high_concept.note: Instantly graspable premise that sells itself in one sentence

cast_attachability.note: Multiple showy roles for comedy stars in both lead and supporting positions

marketing_hook.note: Visual gags and outrageous scenarios make for strong trailer/poster material

budget_return_ratio.note: Can be produced at moderate budget with excellent return potential

comparable_success.note: Recent R-rated wedding comedies show mixed box office, but strong streaming performance

structure_analysis.act_breaks: Act 1 ends around p.25 with the couple's breakup, Act 2 begins with arrival at the wedding destination, midpoint occurs with the whale watching incident (p.50-55), Act 3 begins with the hotel fire and culminates in redemption
structure_analysis.pacing: Fast overall with strong momentum, though some repetition in the second act prank sequences creates minor drag

characters.protagonist: Melissa - photographer with career ambitions whose breakup wounds make her increasingly vindictive; clear goal of 'winning' against her ex
characters.antagonist: Jonathan - startup CEO and Melissa's ex who escalates pranks to prove he's better off without her
supporting: Nicole (uptight bride with a pregnancy secret)
Nick (easygoing groom caught in the crossfire)
Bradford (Melissa's fake gay boyfriend with perfect abs)

standout_scenes.scene: The 'Don't tase me bro' card game
standout_scenes.why: Perfectly escalates the absurdity while showcasing character dynamics

standout_scenes.scene: Whale watching boat disaster with shark fin
standout_scenes.why: Blends physical comedy, revenge, and consequences in a memorable setpiece

standout_scenes.scene: The climactic fight in the banquet hall that burns down the hotel
standout_scenes.why: Visually spectacular payoff that literally and figuratively burns down the characters' facades

comparable_films.title: Bridesmaids
comparable_films.similarity: R-rated wedding comedy with female perspective and outrageous physical comedy

comparable_films.title: Wedding Crashers
comparable_films.similarity: R-rated wedding comedy with romantic elements and escalating situations

comparable_films.title: Palm Springs
comparable_films.similarity: Wedding setting with modern relationship dynamics and existential themes

budget_tier.justification: Single location (tropical resort) with moderate cast size and limited effects needs beyond the climactic fire

strengths: Strong, commercially viable premise that's easy to market
Sharp, contemporary dialogue with memorable lines and distinct character voices
Effective escalation of comedic situations that builds to a satisfying climax
Dual protagonist structure gives both male and female perspectives equal weight
Balance of outrageous comedy with genuine emotional stakes
weaknesses: Some repetitive pranking in the second act creates pacing issues
Several supporting characters remain thinly sketched despite screen time
A few plot contrivances strain credibility even for a comedy (the shark)
The redemption requires significant suspension of disbelief after catastrophic damage
development_notes: Streamline the second act by cutting 1-2 prank sequences to improve pacing
Develop Leah and Bette beyond their current function as minor comic relief
Consider more grounded consequences for the hotel destruction in the resolution
assessment.marketability: high - The premise is immediately graspable, offers multiple casting opportunities for comedy stars, and includes visual set pieces perfect for trailers. The wedding comedy genre continues to perform well, especially with edgier takes.
assessment.recommendation_rationale: With a weighted score of 7.45, strong commercial viability score of 17, and no critical failures, this screenplay demonstrates significant potential. While it falls just short of RECOMMEND thresholds, the commercial appeal, castability, and quality of comedic execution make it worthy of serious consideration.

analysis.verdict_statement: This screenplay shows genuine strength in its instantly graspable concept, sharp dialogue, and escalating comedic scenarios, but requires development attention to pacing issues in the second act and underdeveloped supporting characters. With tightening of the repetitive prank sequences and more dimensional secondary characters, this project could achieve RECOMMEND status.
